questions.question:
The unit interval \((0, 1)\) is divided at a point chosen uniformly distributed over \((0,1)\) in \(\mathbb{R}\) into two disjoint subintervals.

The expected length of the subinterval that contains 0.4 is ___________. (rounded off to two decimal places)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
A quadratic polynomial \((x - \alpha)(x - \beta)\) over complex numbers is said to be square invariant if \((x - \alpha)(x - \beta) = (x - \alpha^2)(x - \beta^2)\). Suppose from the set of all square invariant quadratic polynomials we choose one at random.

The probability that the roots of the chosen polynomial are equal is ______. (rounded off to one decimal place)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let \(\mathcal{F} \) be the set of all functions from \(\{1, \dots, n\} \) to \(\{0,1\} \). Define the binary relation \(\preceq \) on \(\mathcal{F} \) as follows:
\( \forall f, g \in \mathcal{F}, \, f \preceq g \quad \text{if and only if} \quad \forall x \in \{1, \dots, n\}, f(x) \leq g(x), \text{ where } 0 \leq 1. \)
Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)

questions.question:
Consider a probability distribution given by the density function \( P(x) \).

\( P(x) = \begin{cases} Cx^2, &\text{for } 1 \leq x \leq 4 \\ 0, & \text{for }x < 1 \text{ or } x > 4 \end{cases}\)

The probability that \( x \) lies between 2 and 3, i.e., \( P(2 \leq x \leq 3) \) is _________. (rounded off to three decimal places)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Suppose a 5-bit message is transmitted from a source to a destination through a noisy channel. The probability that a bit of the message gets flipped during transmission is 0.01. Flipping of each bit is independent of one another. The probability that the message is delivered error-free to the destination is _________. (rounded off to three decimal places)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
\( A = \{ 0,1,2,3,\dots \} \) is the set of non-negative integers. Let \( {F} \) be the set of functions from \( A \) to itself. For any two functions, \( f_1, f_2 \in {F} \), we define

\( (f_1 \odot f_2)(n) = f_1(n) + f_2(n)\)

for every number \( n \) in \( A \). Which of the following is/are CORRECT about the mathematical structure \( ({F}, \odot ) \)?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following predicate logic formulae/formula is/are CORRECT representation(s) of the statement: "Everyone has exactly one mother"?

The meanings of the predicates used are:
\(mother(y,x): y\) is the mother of \( x \)
\(noteq(x,y): x\) and \( y \) are not equal

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
A.

\( \forall x \exists y \exists z (mother(y, x) \land \neg mother(z, x)) \)

B.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \forall z (noteq(z, y) \to \neg mother(z, x))] \)

C.

\( \forall x \forall y [mother(y, x) \to \exists z (mother(z, x) \land \neg noteq(z, y))] \)

D.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \neg \exists z (noteq(z, y) \land mother(z, x))] \)
correct_answer:
B.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \forall z (noteq(z, y) \to \neg mother(z, x))] \)

D.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \neg \exists z (noteq(z, y) \land mother(z, x))] \)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
A box contains 5 coins: 4 regular coins and 1 fake coin. When a regular coin is tossed, the probability \(P(\text{head}) = 0.5\) and for a fake coin, \(P(\text{head}) = 1\). You pick a coin at random and toss it twice, and get two heads. The probability that the coin you have chosen is the fake coin is _______. (rounded off to two decimal places)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let \(S\) be the set of all ternary strings defined over the alphabet \(\{a, b, c\}\). Consider all strings in \(S\) that contain at least one occurrence of two consecutive symbols, that is, "aa", "bb" or "cc". The number of such strings of length 5 that are possible is _______. (Answer in integer)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
\(g(. )\) is a function from \(A\) to \(B\), \(f(. )\) is a function from \(B\) to \(C\), and their composition defined as \(f(g(. ))\) is a mapping from \(A\) to \(C\).
If \(f(. )\) and \(f(g(. ))\) are onto (surjective) functions, which ONE of the following is TRUE about the function \(g(. )\)?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
C.

\(g(. )\) must be a bijective function, that is, both one-to-one and onto.

D.

\(g(. )\) is not required to be a one-to-one or onto function.
questions.correct_answer:
D.

\(g(. )\) is not required to be a one-to-one or onto function.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
